												I've got to be honest, the first time I played this game I was disappointed.  The combat, both on horseback and on foot, just felt off.  In addition, there is almost no story.  And the graphics are definitely outdated.  So why the positive review?  This is a game that grows on you, but only if you give it time.  The early stages where you have nothing are frustrating, as you can't do much and are easily defeated.  But if you can weather this period, the game opens up as you build up supplies and equipment and soldiers.  In addition, the combat becomes much more intuitive as you spend time with it.  You are soon able to best larger armies due to your skill level, as well as the quality of your equipment and soldiers.  Unfortunately, it's at this point that the game feels a bit broken.  The whole game revolves around several factions that own various towns and are at war with each other, and you generally align yourself with one of these factions.  No matter how well you equip your crew at this point in the game, you almost always encounter insurmountable odds when you face any of the opposing factions in combat.  For example, you might be limited to a party of 60, but will regularly encounter parties of opposing factions that range from 100-200.  Worse yet, even if you're able to best such a large party, it's almost a given that the opposing faction will have another party or two in the area, each with 100+ soldiers.  It never feels like your faction supports you as much as other factions support them.  In addition, conquering all of a faction's towns seems next to impossible as the towns are dispersed over quite a large area on the map.  While you might conquer several towns in one area, it could take you several in-game days to travel to the next area to conquer that faction's remaining towns.  Meanwhile, those initial towns you conquered have been conquered by one of the game's other factions, as you typically spread yourself thin trying to attack so many areas.  Overall, I know that I've pointed out several flaws with this game so far.  That being said, I feel like these issues don't detract from the game so much overall, as addressing them would make the sequel that much better.  I really enjoyed this game, but a sequel that addressed my issues would be worth a lot of money to me.  This game was good, but I look forward to checking out more from this franchise.  I would give this game a 7.5/10.

												I've been gaming for 30+ years and over that time I've played a lot of games. From my experience, Mount & Blade offers a unique gaming experience. Not quite like anything else I've ever played. There are some similarities to familiar games, such as shades of the Total War series, but stark enough differences that they really cannot be compared. Mount & Blade in my opinion is fairly easy to learn, but does take some skill with action type fighting to be mastered. If you enjoy strategy games with a turn based feel, mixed with real time combat, in a non-linear world; then Mount & Blade may just well be your cup of tea. I was looking for a somewhat decent strategy game that would run on my gutless business laptop and I have to say I was not expecting as good of a game as it turned out to truly be. It's got enough meat in the vanilla campaign to keep most people busy for at least 100 hours I would speculate, though I personally have already invested 200 hours into my first vanilla campaign and can see it dragging out another 100-200 easily. 												Mount & Blade is a game that wants to be it all and while the lack of polish makes it fail in a lot of places the solid design behind it all makes it succeed in many more.At it's core Mount & Blade is a hack and slash game, and by that I don't mean one button for light swing, one button for power swing. Using either mouse or keyboard you can select a myriad of different attacks and blocks depending on the weapon you're using as you engage in high intensity melee's with hundreds of opponents.You play the game in two modes, the world map and the battle map. The world map is where you walk your hero across the land, recruit soldiers, buy weapons and goods and find bands of enemies to fight. When you go into battle you are transported onto a procedurally generated battle map where you get you fight your enemies with whatever weapons and soldiers are at your disposal. Although both of these modes are plagued with a number of bugs and rather noticeable lack of polish the core of the fighting remains fun and challenging and makes you forgive the flaws you may encounter.Graphically Mount & Blade is nothing too impressive. It's full of rough edges and flat surfaces and you know it's an indie title when you play it. The sound is similarly lacking and not much to talk about.But despite all it's flaws this is just one of those few rare games that manages to live through a low budget, bad tech and broken features through a strong and simple core mechanic. The fighting is excellent and there are enough mods available to remedy many of the problems on the world map. Although this is a title that will never quite feel like it should be classic it still manages to hold a strong place in your memory.Although this is an excellent game that I throughly enjoyed playing it is not one I would recommend you buy these days simply because the Warband standalone expansion is pretty much just an updated version of this.

Yes, it's graphics are horrid, and yes, there are a few small bugs left in there, but wow, I'm currently clocked in at 63 hours, and I know that I've at least a few more days to go until I'm satisfied with this game, and even then, I'll probably make a new character just to follow another king.This game is amazing, terrific, wonderful, and much more! If you are someone who can't stand playing on Easy, then this might be a bit rough for you and your armies.I cannot reccomend this game enough, ecspecially to those who love build-your-army type games! Once you have a feel for all the weaponry (small changes make big differences), and what race of soldier can accomplish what, you can progress rather well, and this game has been nothing but fun all the way!But it! 												Overall: so much fun! You get a great combination of action in the medieval combat, strategy in the larger scale battles, and role-playing game classics such as choosing alliances and missions, leveling up, and suiting up.With that said, the role-playing aspect couldn't be considered truly complete on its own. Your personal relationships with lords, for instance, does indeed evolve somewhat and have an impact on the options available to you, but the relationship mechanisms in place are a little shallow. This part of the game sort of comes across as a roleplaying sandbox and only a stick to dig with. Combat and looting also suffer some issues, but overall the combat system is pretty satisfying (though you'll see what I'm talking about when you're trying to pick up weapons in the tournaments). A variety of fairly viable combat styles are available to your character, though you'll usually have to adapt to the context of the battle. Speaking of the battle contexts, you're offered a number of different scenarios, from open battles on the field to raiding throne rooms to laying siege to cities or castles. You can thus get a nice taste sword and shield battle atop a wall as well hit-and-run with mounted archery in the field. These styles and contexts also flow nicely out of the nature of your army and their background, with the Khergit, Swadians, Rhodoks, Vaegirs, and Nords differing significantly in their typical strategies. For many people that enjoy these games, the tactics surrounding match ups between these factions is the heart of what makes the game unique.Anyway, overall awesome. I look forward to trying the Warband expansion where some things will be fixed and some content will be added.

												Life is short if you're not on a horse: the game.Holy cow is this game addictive!  The very first thing I noticed was that the graphics are a bit dated; there are sprites and menus that could use some work, and some of the animations have some glitches here and there.  It just doesn't have the polish and motion capture sparkle of modern games and I thought that would translate into me hating it.  But, the actual game play is addictive and exhilerating.Start off with the fact that this game is a sandbox.  You are not the chosen one, the world does not revolve around your actions, your story is exactly what you make it and nothing more.  This means you travel where you want, do what you want and you weather the consequences.  I got the feeling that I was a very small cog in a very big machine and for once I felt like a game gave me a sense of perspective.The strategic map offers it's own set of challenges as forces of varying strength roam the world looking for fights.  You have to pick your battles, and keep your eyes open for opportunities.  Then when you get on the battlefield, it is all hard charging and bloodshed and life just being awful for footsoldiers.  Honestly, I've gotten to the point where the biggest threat to me is a cramp in my axe arm, and I feel a little bad for those poor schmucks on the other side of the map.  The action could use some tinkering, but I've been having so much fun playing it, I can't say that it is really broken.I bought this game on sale and got my money's worth.  It's worth more than that.  I've had a lot of fun!

Posted: June 1, 2011
												I have spent the last month of my gaming history pretty much exclusively playing this, and every moment of it was a blast! The game blends RPG elements with Empire building and real-time combat in a convincing and realistic medieval world (extremely rare in the genre!). Unlike most games M&B doesn't even try to hide the darker aspects of the middle ages but embraces them: women don't have anything to say, the aristocracy reigns supreme and slavery is everywhere. Human life is cheap, and you are a foreigner who has yet to make a name for him/her self when you start your adventure in the fictonal land of Calradia.You will find no elves, trolls or magic spells in this game. You will find a grim world modelled after Europe and parts of the middle east and Asia in the Dark Ages. The adventruring/empire management interface is clunky, but the battles are truly brutal. Especially castle sieges are good fun. Expect to see your character covered in arrows and gore at the end of the battle!

Posted: April 8, 2013
												Best combat on horse or foot that I've played so far. Realistic combat mechanics, both on foot and mounted; the game's strong point is a simulation of combat on horseback.Visually impressive even though this game is already a few years old. The environment rendering like the dynamic lighting of day and night cycles and occasional weather effects like fog or rain are convincing. Graphic details are very much customizable.Game is very flexible and non-linear; you are free to do as you please; stay neutral or pick sides, hunt bandits or do quests, in any order and at your own pace. Issue tactical commands during 1st person battle or strategic commands on the world map. Strategic commands are only available after joining a faction and after being elected as the marshal.Use your marshal appointment to mobilize a huge battalion and engage on a war path OR NOT. NPC AI in battle and pathfinding is adequate. If the lords are not mobilized, they will most likely patrol or do their own thing; they may also occasionally attempt to besige a castle but they will not coordinate with other lords unless you're not the marshal but just one of the house lords, in which case, another marshall will coordinate the army. So if you don't want the game to end so soon, don't coordinate a castle siege.Though character class is non-existent, role-playing elements are quite extensive. Distribute attributes & skill points to your preferred style of play. Weapon proficiency increases through usage. Neither magic nor alchemy is needed here; the setting of this game is medieval fiction rather than mythological fantasy but it has enough interesting elements, depth of gameplay & replayability to draw you back and try something new.Ahh, before I end this lengthy justification of a recommendation, I do have a few gripes about M&B, albeit minor ones. One is that morale of the party gradually goes down over time; the bigger the party the faster it declines and morale only gets a major boost after a major battle is won, this makes it virtually imperative to look for trouble to keep the troops happy even though they are always paid on time and adequately supplied with a variety of food types. If the troops do not get their fix of adrenaline they may eventually desert your party. Luckily bandits roam about all the time, you just have to be fast enough to nail them. As you might have guessed by now, the other thing is that troop maintenance is high, so you got to constantly fight in tournaments, look for quests, sell loot, sell prisoners to the slave market, or collect taxes but by far the most lucrative way of earning money is placing bets in the tournaments, looting enemy villages or extorting from enemy caravans. No rest for the weary.Despite its aggravating tendencies, this game does integrates aspects of role-play, strategy, action and simulation equally well in a neat polished package and this kind of inclusive gameplay I have not seen nor played before, hence my recommendation.

												Mount & Blade is a fantastic action-strategy-RPG with the best horseback-based fighting engine I have ever experienced. 												At first glance, M&B seems like another bland Medieval Combat game. It was designed by a Turkish Couple and, let's be honest, isn't the prettiest game in this generation. As the age old mantra "Never Judge a Book By It's Cover" states, however, Mount and Blade is much more than meets the eye. The game is a full simulation of a land dominated by several kingdoms, each one vyying for domination. In the center of the chaos is you; a lone sellsword whose only advantage is indomitable will and a (possible) noble background. The game allows you to do whatever you please; swear fealty to a king, ascend the ladder of nobility through marriage and political gaming, raise an army and siege castles and strongholds, compete in tournaments for honor and cash, or just spend your days ambushing caravans and living off of the spoils. There's no wrong way to play the game and no matter what method you choose, you'll have fun. The game also boasts a fantastic combat system and several mods. Get it.

												Everything starts somewhere, right? And with Mount & Blade TaleWorlds truly took a giant leap into the gaming world.Mount & Blade is a excellent Open World Strategy RPG. Why the strange genre? Well, simply put I find it really hard to put it under just one label. It's open world in the way that you can travel anywhere whenever you want. It's a strategy game because you need to utilize your smarts and plan your army according to what enemy you face. Yet it's an RPG because of the levelling system and the different skills and specializations.But to be honest this game is not worth it. If there is anything we should all know by now it is that Mount & Blade: Warband (A sequel of sorts) is exactly like it's predecessor except 100% better. So the reason I do not recommend this game is because I would strongly urge you to buy Warband instead for all the added features and because the map was greatly improved. So don't get me wrong, this is a wonderful game but the sequel does everything this game can do but a hundred times better.

												Pretty much a sandbox RPG, which is not really as great as it sounds.  The quests are completely dull and the entire story amounts to some exposition and the odd feature that your enemies prefer to capture you and take your stuff rather than simply kill you so that you won't take revenge in the future.It's a good experiment in seeing how many fiefs or territory you can acquire, or whether you can outfit your guy in the most expensive armor before he bites the poverty bullet or you get too bored with it.I played with this game for many hours, which is to say, i experimented with it.  The combat is a mildly interesting wargame about conserving troop morale with the power of food, blocking and annoyingly aim-centric swinging that avoids combos and feels more like D&D due to how much easier it is to miss the opponent instead of actually hit them or get blocked by them (except when you're on foot), making sure you have enough horses and the right weather and time of day to optimize your travel speed across the map graphic, verbally telling off your follower NPCs for arguing with each other, and a bunch of other stuff that is really only interesting in concept rather than presentation or follow through.The only real merit, is of course, mounted combat against forces on foot, cheesey castle sieges that aren't worth much after the first few (or 10 or so, if you're me), and the concept of the game itself.FINAL SCORE: 55.

												I got this game a week or so ago. I wanted to try something new. I figured what the heck...it's only 10 bucks. Best 10 bucks I've spent in a long time. The graphics are dated, but so is the game. I'm playing basically as a mercenary. Here's the skinny. Start off in the arena fighting in the cities. You'll get better at using your horse in the tournaments and weapons in the gladiator-style 40-man matches. It's a good way to practice and earn extra money. An important rule of thumb. Losing in the arena will not cost you anything. Losing a battle outside the cities...you're going to lose money and people if you've recruited any. Once you've gotten up some cash to spare upgrade your armor and whatever weapon you choose to use.I started out in the Vaegir Kingdom way up in the snow. Be sure to attack only looters to begin with. Usually they spawn about 5-10 at a time. I beat 10 of them by myself. I even took out 11 Swadian foot soldiers. Loot their stuff until your slots are full then head to the nearest city and sell everything except better gear for yourself. Little by little as I recruited guys from the small towns I moved toward the Kindom of the Nords by the ocean. I started to drive off sea-raiders. Sea-raiders have the most expensive equipment. Wipe out enough of them and after a while your renown get you noticed by one of the lords. You'll get sent a notice asking if you'd like to become a vassal. You swear allegiance to him. He'll give you a fief. ( A town somewhere in the kingdom you run and collect taxes from.) From there keep an eye on your town, help it grow to make more money, keep chasing looters, raiders, etc...doing quests, and defending your kingdom. When things get to the point that raiders aren't poppng up as much you can always raid an enemy town. Carefuil! watch your map so you don't get ambushed. I tried to fight my way out once but I was ounumber by 40 Swadians who took me prisoner. They stole 6,000 in denars and about 19 of my party members. I went from 25 to 6. Plus, it really makes your enemy much more♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off. You make ALOT of money off of the spices and oils and tools you don't get from a battle. I love it!
